title: Eastern Hemisphere
text:
The Eastern Hemisphere is a <a href="geography">geographical</a> term for the half of <a href="Earth">Earth</a> which is east of the <a href="prime%20meridian%20%28Greenwich%29">prime meridian</a> (which crosses <a href="Greenwich">Greenwich</a>, <a href="London">London</a>, <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>) and west of the <a href="180th%20meridian">antimeridian</a> (which crosses the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> and relatively little land from pole to pole). It is also used to refer to <a href="Afro-Eurasia">Afro-Eurasia</a> (<a href="Africa">Africa</a> and <a href="Eurasia">Eurasia</a>) and <a href="Australia%20%28continent%29">Australia</a>, in contrast with the <a href="Western%20Hemisphere">Western Hemisphere</a>, which includes mainly <a href="North%20America">North</a> and <a href="South%20America">South America</a>. The Eastern Hemisphere may also be called the "Oriental Hemisphere." In addition, it may be used in a <a href="cultural%20geography">cultural</a> or <a href="geopolitics">geopolitical</a> sense as a synonym for the "<a href="Old%20World">Old World</a>."
Geography.
The almost perfect circle (the earth is an <a href="oblate%20spheroid">oblate spheroid</a> that is fatter around the equator), drawn with a line, demarcating the Eastern and Western Hemispheres must be an arbitrarily decided and published convention, unlike the <a href="Equator">Equator</a> (an imaginary line encircling <a href="Earth">Earth</a>, equidistant from its <a href="geographical%20pole">poles</a>), which divides the <a href="Northern%20Hemisphere">Northern</a> and <a href="Southern%20Hemisphere">Southern</a> Hemispheres. The <a href="prime%20meridian">prime meridian</a> at 0° <a href="longitude">longitude</a> and the <a href="180th%20meridian">antimeridian</a>, at 180° longitude, are the conventionally accepted boundaries, since they divide eastern longitudes from western longitudes. This convention was established in 1884 at the <a href="International%20Meridian%20Conference">International Meridian Conference</a> held in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> where the <a href="standard%20time">standard time</a> concepts of <a href="Canadians">Canadian</a> railroad engineer Sir <a href="Sandford%20Fleming">Sandford Fleming</a> were adopted. The Hemispheres agreed do not correspond with exact continents. Portions of <a href="Western%20Europe">Western Europe</a>, <a href="West%20Africa">West Africa</a>, <a href="Oceania">Oceania</a>, and extreme northeastern <a href="Russia">Russia</a> are in the Western Hemisphere, divorcing it from the continents which form the touchstone for most geopolitical constructs of "the East" and "the West".
Consequently, the meridians of <a href="20th%20meridian%20west">20°W</a> and the diametrically opposed <a href="160th%20meridian%20east">160°E</a> are often used outside of matters of physics and navigation, which includes all of the European and African mainlands, but also includes a small portion of northeast <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a> (typically reckoned as part of <a href="North%20America">North America</a>) and excludes more of eastern Russia and Oceania (e.g., <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>). Prior to the global adoption of standard time, numerous <a href="prime%20meridian">prime meridian</a>s were decreed by various countries where time was defined by local noon (thereby, local ).
The center of the Eastern Hemisphere is located in the <a href="Indian%20Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> at the intersection of the equator and the <a href="90th%20meridian%20east">90th meridian east</a>, 910 km west of <a href="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> in the <a href="Ninety%20East%20Ridge">Ninety East Ridge</a>. The nearest land is <a href="Simeulue">Simeulue</a> Island at .
The land mass of the Eastern Hemisphere is larger than that of the Western Hemisphere and has a wide variety of <a href="habitat">habitat</a>s.
Demographics.
82% of <a href="human">human</a>s live in the Eastern Hemisphere, and 18% in the Western Hemisphere.
